dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: The sky is pure blue, exquisitely blemished by huge cumul clouds, floating lazily. A single bird sails past. From t sky the CAMERA MOVES TO earth. Here, too, all is tranquil The trees, bright green in the sunlight, move only to the slight but constant breeze. Now the CAMERA MOVES DOWN,  revealing a wagon to which is hitched a team of horses be the road. The wagon is at an awkward angle, but upright. is wedged between two rocks where the horses have pulled as they tried to reach some forage. Its seat is empty. In the bed of the wagon several sacks lie, bearing the legen From: Argus Mine - Rock Pass To: U.S. Assay Office San Francisco

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sacks are empty and slashed as by a knife. The ropes  that bound them are cleanly severed. The disorder in the  wagon indicates haste. Two horses are hitched to it, munc grass or the high leaves of a tree overhead. All that is or unnatural is that the reins have fallen askew and trai the ground. Now the CAMERA MOVES AWAY and ALONG tracks made by the wa when it left the road. ON THE ROAD two horses stand. Thes are saddled, but riderless. The rifle holsters are empty. CAMERA MOVES TO the ground. There on the road lies the ri The dust is slightly blowing across it, moved by the  persistent summery little breeze. From the rifle, the CAM MOVES ON A LITTLE and STOPS ABRUPTLY ON the sprawled dead figure of a soldier, then another, face down in the road. CLOSE SHOT of the dead soldiers, as the CAMERA HOLDS ON t Near the hand of one a revolver lies, the fine dust coati it. Dust blowing over the uniforms, as though seeking to  hide the shame of a murder. As it blows over their still  figures, the SOUND of BIRDS coming over:

dialogues.speaker: ROCK PASS
dialogues.text: This is a western mining town of the Eighties that has  mushroomed up around a gold strike. On the streets prospe and miners mingle with merchants. As the CAMERA PICKS UP scene, a lumber wagon passes, bearing logs, a ten team wa its trailer filled with ore from the stamp mills and bear the legend: ARGUS MINE. A stage coach comes in as we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the hotel clerk, as he sits behind the desk, playing a guitar and singing pensively the ballad of the story. As sings, JOHN HAVEN, newly arrived on the stagecoach, walks in, gazes at the clerk with a slight smile, finding the c completely indifferent to the arrival of anybody, at last leaves the bag and saunters out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven leaves the hotel and has reached the saloon, a w lighted, plush-looking spot, illumined by kerosene flares Sticking a pipe in his mouth, Haven saunters in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a huge elaborate room, lit by overhead chandeliers. long mahogany bar runs the length of it. To one side ther is a big stove and the gambling tables. Beyond can be see pool tables in an alcove. To another side, a man grinds a at a piano. A stairway near the end of the bar leads to a upper floor. The place is crowded and noisy with people.  Haven saunters towards the dice table, pauses, watches; h is looking the crowd over carefully -- missing no detail the place or the people in it. When his turn comes, he pi up the dice, bets all over the place -- on the line, on t odds, on the seven, then on the come, the hard way, etc. point is eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight the hard way! Pay the line!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven bets again, doubling all over the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven a winner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Players glance at the newcomer. Prince appears from nowhe standing behind the stickman, watching. Prince is slender black-haired, handsome and impassive. Haven throws again. Stellman, an Army officer, watches curiously. There is a  little rising murmur as Haven tosses another natural. He  does it without enthusiasm or any lost movement. The bett get down on him. Prince touches the stickman's arm; the m stands aside and Prince takes his place with the stick. P tosses the dice back to Haven. Haven's eyes are fixed on  him. With a little smile, Haven throws the dice to the ne man, picks up his winnings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes meet Prince's again and then he turns away, Prin gaze following him curiously, Stellman looks at Prince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just seems kind of free with that  money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS Haven, as still smiling slightly, he heads towards the bar, searching the faces of the crowd as he g Two miners are squared off for a fight and Haven, going h way, walks between them, very indifferent, not even glanc back at the SOUND of scuffle behind him. AT THE BAR - Haven alone is not watching the fight. All t others have turned to see it; even the barman is busy  watching. But Haven's eyes are resting on the figure of a woman now at the piano, singing. Softly, as if to herself and for her own enjoyment. He is near the end of the bar near the piano, and since no one else listens to her at t moment, she sings, half smiling, directly for him, and th self-consciously, she stops and turns to sit at a table, Haven watches her. Behind them the fight is being stopped and Charlie's eyes follow the huge bouncer, Mick Marion, he drags the offenders out to the door and the street. Al is as usual. The bartender is back at work. As Haven turn he finds that the place beside him is now occupied by the young Lieutenant (Phil Stellman). Haven glances at the  uniform, then at the pleasant face of the officer, as the barman comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to barman) Whiskey -- like you'd pour it for  yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl sidles up to him, blonde, brash and pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you know it's no fun to drink  alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not till after the first one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns his back to her; she gives him a look and saunte off. The barman produces the drinks -- a beer for Stellma the young officer. The barman folds his arms. Stellman lo at Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a stranger here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to barman, after  gulping it in one  gulp) What kind of whiskey was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the bottle it says Rye -- but the  way you take it, I don't see what  difference it makes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another Rye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barman turns to get it. Stellman is still looking at  Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easily) You didn't answer my question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a stranger everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barman gives Haven another Rye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, soldier. I know that one,  too. Got a job, stranger? No? Why  don't you join the Army? Three meals  a day, a place to sleep, a nice warm  uniform --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has a little more than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deliberately) Yeah, it has one thing more, and  that's what I could never take -- (looking at Stellman's  stripes) It's got Second-Lieutenants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barman, listening, senses trouble and signals with hi eyes to a big bouncer down the bar. The bouncer moves up  quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to make it a personal  matter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) I don't make it anything, soldier.  You tried to sell something and I  didn't buy it -- so why don't you  just beat it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at each other for a long second, then Stellman speaks icily:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I weren't in uniform, I might  teach you some manners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could teach me anything, you  wouldn't be in a uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stellman's jaw tightens; then he turns and exits abruptly The barman sighs with relief; the bouncer turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't be looking for trouble,  could you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could, but I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine, because this is one of  the best places West of the Atlantic  Ocean to find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was my first impression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Haven looks at  him) That Lieutenant's a nice young boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't doubt it, but his mouth is  too big -- like your ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away from the bar, after flipping a coin on to i while the barman stands there not knowing whether to be a or philosophical. CAMERA FOLLOWS Haven, as he threads his way through the t towards the door. His eyes catch sight of the girl who sa at the piano, Charlie. She is sitting at a table with Pri Prince murmurs to her and she glances at Haven, then look away again. Haven notes it. As he comes near the table, t blonde who spoke to him at the bar, accosts him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is it now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drinking alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flipping her a coin) It's all right -- try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven is looking at Charlie. She is checking a stack of c the blonde has turned in to her. She glances up with a  fleeting smile at Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a good habit if it makes  you pick fights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only with Second Lieutenants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We like Second Lieutenants here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their gazes meet and Prince notes it with narrowing eyes. The gaze holds like a spell, and then Charlie's smile com back, from nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see -- here everybody fights,  except the Army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven looks at her, fascinated. She can feel a fascinatio herself. Now Haven smiles a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still smiling) So anyone who doesn't like the Army --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you mean, but I'm afraid  I'll have to come back. I like the  way you sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him in a second's silence. Haven turns and  leaves. She watches him go. Prince studies her face, his grim. A croupier comes up and places a paper before her. hardly notices it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie snaps out of it long enough to initial the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's his limit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a sucker getting hot with  the dice at Ed's table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away. Prince sits still, his eyes on Charlie, hi slim fingers at an habitual trick, that of idly stacking  dice in a little pillar and then picking the pillar aloft holding the lowest dice pinched between the thumb and  forefinger, NOT by the edges, but by the sides. Now he do it as he watches Charlie's face. Her eyes glance again at the disappearing back of Haven. The sense of fascination  seems to have gotten her, too. Then she realizes the pres of Prince and his shrewd gaze. She looks at him coolly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- cool him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince flips the dice into his palm and rises...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The board sidewalk has given way to a rutty dirt road. No the racket of the saloon street is just a ghost of noise, the road dark and silent. Haven has emerged from the salo He glances up the street. Fifty yards ahead, Stellman is  walking slowly. Stellman pauses, shoots a quick glance  backwards, then goes on. Haven follows, going leisurely u the street after Stellman. ANGLE on a corner as Stellman turns it, pauses and waits. When Haven reaches it, Stellman goes on in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stellman reaches it, pauses and glances behind him. Th he rings a bell. Haven comes up and waits in silence, gla at the dark interior. A woman's face now peers through th door window and then the door opens. Stellman enters quic and Haven follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stellman and Haven follow Mrs. Caslon to a rear door.  Looking around, Haven notes in the shadows a desk and in corner the big safe. (This room is described in a subsequ scene.) So as to emit the least light, Mrs. Caslon lets  Stellman and Haven go through, then quickly follows them quickly shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is remarkably neat and elegant inside. As Haven, glanc around, pauses inside, he finds himself facing a burly  uniformed cavalry officer, captain's bars gleaming on the side of his collar. The captain is big and broad and scow He is standing by the fireplace and his eyes are boring i Haven's with curiosity and perhaps, suspicion. Stellman s forward as Haven and the captain are measuring each other

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Iles -- the Commanding Officer  of the Post.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven gives a casual nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Haven -- sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iles looks him up and down. Haven hands him an envelope w he slips into his tunic without removing his gaze from Ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you finally got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) I seem to finally get everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They eye each other, Iles scowling, Haven thinly smiling. The sense of conflict is already between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (introducing) Mrs. Caslon, -- Mr. Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods and smiles warmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've met Mr. Stellman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It came off beautifully. He picks a  very good fight. In fact, I think  I'm still a little sore at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grunting) Sit down, Mr. Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down. Iles is still studying Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're operating under sealed  orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven nods agreeably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgruntled) All this mumbo jumbo is characteristic  of the Military Information  Department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We use it as sparingly as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iles pulls out a cigar, lights it, sizing Haven up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been in this territory for a  number of years -- and I think it  might be a little rougher here than  a suburb of Washington, D.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very possibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why is M.I.D. sending you out  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because two soldiers have been  murdered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they think I can't handle that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They merely know you haven't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a tight little silence, while Iles formulates hi dislike for this newcomer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have only ninety-four men on the  post, with Indian trouble up north.  The War Department has refused to  send reinforcements, or am I boring  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking bored) I'm not the War Department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explaining) The two soldiers were killed while  escorting one of the gold stages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Is escorting gold a function of your  command?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young man, the functions of my command  look very pretty on paper, but they're  not very practical in a territory  like this. Do you have any illusions  about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no illusions about anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven takes out his pipe and fills it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happening to the gold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've permitted it to be stored in a  warehouse on the post. Now everybody  is waiting to see what I do next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with sarcasm) Aren't you here to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lighting the pipe) Captain, you're in a bad way. (going over to discard  the match) Wells Fargo won't convoy gold. You  tried and failed and two men are  dead. The gold is piling up on the  post and you can't move it. Your  post is under-manned. You want the  Quartermaster at Platte to replace  seventy uniforms sent to the freight  office at West Rim City --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The freight building burned down  with the uniforms! I'm not operating  a fire department -- and if I was,  West Rim City is sixty miles away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't concern me either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The killing of two soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were my men, Haven, and I'm  trying every way I know to find out  who murdered them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So will I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time Iles looks amicably at him, as though  realizing that after all the man isn't there to criticize him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll find it harder than you think.  I don't know how you operate, but  it's a dangerous job that can get  you killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles slightly at Iles, who gives him a slight smile return, somehow intrigued by this nonchalance. Haven rise from the chair, lighting the dead pipe in vain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I can get some help from the  Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can forget him. He's a miserable  man that somebody is using to keep  the law a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make it sound very difficult.  Why don't you just wrap up your flag  and take it back East with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smarting) Tell me, how will I know what you're  doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll let you know from time to time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) That's very obliging of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't want to visit the Army  post.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then report to me through Mrs. Caslon  here. You can be a friend of her  husband's. He owned the Argus mine  and died last year. If that meets  your approval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven glances at Mrs. Caslon, smiles back at Iles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if it meets with hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be delighted to help. (she smiles at Haven)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grim at the smile) Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iles marches out abruptly, followed by Stellman. The door shuts. Haven smiles after him, then at Mrs. Caslon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He really isn't that abrupt -- he --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens again, smartly, Iles marches back in, kiss Mrs. Caslon on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warmly) Goodnight, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he marches out again, shutting the door after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he secretly likes you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a man who can sure keep a secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Would you like a little sherry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if you have some too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes over to a sideboard and pours a little from a  decanter into two wine glasses. Haven watches her. For th first time he realizes she is a very attractive woman. Sh smiles as she brings him the wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To your good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven nods and they sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What mine did the two soldiers try  to convoy the gold from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mine -- The Argus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling a little) That brings me to a question I decided  not to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling back at him) Then I'll answer it first. Captain  Iles has asked me to marry him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can understand that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) But you can't understand why Captain  Iles should be involved in the gold  business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) I do now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't just mine. You must realize  there's a lot of gold from all over  the territory stored at the post  warehouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps as much as half a million. (worried now) In fact, I have about fifty thousand  in my safe now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is doing all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... that's the worst  part of it... not knowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puts down the glass,  pats her shoulder  with casual  reassurance) I might find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts for the door and she follows him. At the open d he pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get into trouble --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. Trouble and I  are old enemies. We understand each  other. (he grins at her) Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling again) Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven walks out and she closes the door thoughtfully and  turns away. In a moment the door opens and Haven reenters and crosses to her much in the manner that we have seen  Captain Iles do so. Haven stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't tell me your husband's  name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeating it) Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and goes out the door. Mrs. Caslon stands smilin after him. The smile fades for a moment -- then she dismi it with a shrug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven saunters along. He pauses, glances up at a sign  that reads: HOTEL. Then he enters the dingy building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven enters the small dismal lobby, and goes over to desk, where a little man, Orville Weekly sits, singing to himself softly and strumming an accompaniment on a batter guitar. As Haven stands there the clerk finishes the vers about the stranger. Haven nods approval. The clerk looks him shrewdly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evenin' stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must know everybody in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody but one. I don't know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name? You seem to be a  pretty clever fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orville Weekly, and I can't be a  total blank. I been here six years  and I ain't dead yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got a vacant room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Day, week, month?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't always know. And the way you  talk a man couldn't be very sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it's eight bucks, cash in  advance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven puts down the money; the clerk spins the registry t him, watches as Haven signs it. And he can read that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Arizona, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I always put down where I'm  going next -- so I won't forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk spits, hands him a key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room ten -- end of the hall. Make  your own bed. Furnish your own towels.  Your bag's over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up the key) Thanks a lot for the key. I'll be  back later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven crosses to exit into the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven enters. It is crowded. Haven pauses by a table. sees Charlie at the piano singing. He sees Mick cross to  Prince and say something, then Prince gazes in his direct Haven's eyes meet those of Prince suddenly turned to him, cold as glass. Charlie, seeing that Haven is watching and listening to her impromptu singing, stops and makes her w through the crowd towards a booth off the dance floor. Ha eyes follow her. MED. SHOT - of booth as Charlie sits down. A sandwich is  waiting for her. She takes a bite of it, then glances up see Haven standing beside the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about eating alone? Is that a  bad habit too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just when you have to pay for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only money. (sitting down) I've changed my mind since I left  here awhile ago. I don't want to  pick a fight -- or break the bank --  or --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evenly) What changed your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) That's what I came back to find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie glances at him, then at the crowd where Mick Mari stands beside Prince. Both are looking coldly towards the booth. Haven's gaze follows hers towards Mick, as Prince  leaves the big man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it would be better if you found  another girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) No, it wouldn't... I looked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles slightly back at him, glances away towards Mic Haven looks too, curiously. Mick is still watching, coldl Others glance too, as though this were an unexpected thin Mick takes a drink from a passing waiter; kills it in one gulp. Haven looks back at Charlie's face and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man in ape's clothing -- could  he be Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes follow you around like a  couple of flies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They follow me to see that strangers  don't annoy me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only strangers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one else would be so foolish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First, you're beautiful. Then I like  the way you sing -- and now you're a  woman of mystery. (to a passing waiter) Champagne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter nods and leaves. Charlie is still gazing at Ha with that slight provocative smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be a stranger, so  I'll have to be foolish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like to take chances, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I feel lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'd advise you to try the dice  table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather get lucky here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging) Every man has a right to go to his  own funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as the waiter sets  down the champagne  and glasses) I could be your cousin from  Waxahatchio. I could be cousin John,  a missionary on his way to China.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter leaves, as Charlie still regards Haven with a  curious interest. Haven is glancing again toward Mick, ju as that animal barrels down another whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems to be a lot of man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment Prince comes into scene and sits at the ta Haven looks at him but Charlie offers no introduction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a very small town. (he sips and gazes  around) You could get it all in this saloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We usually do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Charlie probably runs the town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (toying with his dice) Why do you care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to spend some time here. I  want to know who winds the clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances up and a slow smile comes over his face as Mic Marion is seen approaching deliberately and with cold men Her eyes follow his, then back to his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a nice conversation. I  hate to have it end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blank-faced and big, Mick arrives at the booth. He stares from Charlie to Haven. Haven looks at him then at Charlie Charlie watches Haven's face, but the smile remains. It s to sway her, this little test of expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a taut pause) Mick -- this is -- cousin John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved) From Waxahatchie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mick is not quite sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's keeping him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he's wondering if he couldn't  do more good here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven senses now it is a little game they're playing toge on him. His smile remains. He reaches for the bottle, his hand grasping the base of it, just as Mick reaches for it too, clenching the top. Mick lifts at it; Haven's hand ho They look at each other as this little game of strength g on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You aren't very friendly, are you,  mister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quoting) A friend to all is a friend to none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to learn not to pick 'em  so easy, like you do your cousins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Charlie) Ask her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly) I never saw him before in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That does it. Mick wrenches at the bottle, and as he does so, Haven releases his grip. The bottle shoots up. The wi spills over Mick's face and clothes. Infuriated, Mick fli the bottle at Haven, but Haven ducks as he comes out of t chair. The bottle crashes against the wall, and Haven's f crashes against Mick. The big man grunts and staggers bac but he doesn't drop. As Haven sets himself, he is suddenl pinned from behind by two bouncers. Mick stands still, st at him, his cut lip bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (icily) You're too little to make that big a  mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to correct me or just bleed  at the mouth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a dead silence. At the crap table the dice read  seven but no one looks at them, all turning toward the sc A minor rises and the girl on his lap hits the floor. A d steals a drink and no one sees him. (Business with glass) Prince looks on coldly. Mark Bristow, moving up from the  dice table, pauses and stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) Bring him outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two bouncers start with Haven toward the door, Mick  following. A rear rises and men begin following in their  silent wake. Only the guy at the piano keeps on playing: never stops. ANGLE on Charlie as she rises. Bristow and Prince have  sauntered over to her as the place empties, leaving only piano player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually) A misunderstanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you find out what he wants?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting out) He wanted to be my cousin. (they follow her) Only I haven't any aunts or uncles. (still casually) But you never know -- and the least  I can do is bury him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince lets go with one of his rare smiles as he looks  admiringly at Charlie. They reach the door. The crowd ope for them a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mick and Haven come out; the crowd makes a noisy clear There are bets going down. As soon as the crowd has forme an open space, Haven wheels and smacks Mick across the fa hitting with the heel of the hand, so that Mick rocks bac almost going down. There is dead silence. Mick sets himse for the Kill, as he peels his coat. Bristow is shaking with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mick will kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's ten to one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) I don't like the other fellow's  chances, but I'm a sucker for odds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should always bet on a champion.  Then you can only lose once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You give ten to one...? (she nods) I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're down. A thousand to a hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they stare at the fight -- FULL SHOT - fight scene. As Mick is slowly advancing towa Haven. He suddenly swings a haymaker which Haven easily d another and another that Haven evades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't miss so much. You'll got tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mick misses again, fiercely and Haven cracks him one in t midriff. Then steps out fast and waits. Mick charges and Haven catches him full in the mouth. It  stops Mick, and then Haven socks him again, this time wit the butt of his hand -- open palm -- on the nose. Mick is surprised, tasting the blood on his hurt lips. ANGLE on Charlie, Mark and Prince, as they watch. Charlie eyes are fixed with a kind of admiration on Haven. Prince watches without interest. Mark is tense and excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can fight a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little won't be enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you feel she wishes it might... ANGLE on the fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand still and fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mick closes again, Haven stops quickly to one side,  clipping him behind the ear as he goes by. But this time  Mick keeps after Haven and finally connects. It is more o push than a clean hit, but even so the force of it drives Haven off balance and he sprawls on his back. As Mick, se victory, charges, Haven knows he can't get to his feet in time, so he turns his body and springs at Mick's knees  shoulder first. The impact spills Mick on his face; befor he can recover, Haven dives on him, hands flat on his own chest and palms turned out. His body crashes heavily, ang across Mick's head, and Haven's savagely pushing hands ma the other man's face into the hard ground. Then he rolls  clear and comes to his feet, breathing easily, waiting. M gets up, shaking his head to clear it, mad and hurt. As h closes ponderously in on Haven, his booted foot suddenly  shoots out. Haven twists his knee cap away but takes the  blow on the inside of his thigh, numbing the leg so that almost goes down. And now Mick gets to him. His great arm close around Haven's waist, his hands locked in the small Haven's back. Haven braces himself against the crushing  squeeze, tensing his back muscles and stiffening his spin but there is nothing he can do against the implacable bru power of the other man. The sweat stands out on Haven's face as Mick's great stre bends him over farther and farther. He must do something, and soon, or his back will be cracked like a barrel stave Suddenly he bends his knees and lifts his feet up from of the ground. Mick, suddenly finding Haven's full weight pu him forward, crashes down on top of him. With all the str left in him, Haven brings his knee to the pit of Mick's  stomach; as Mick's hold breaks, Haven rolls clear. Now they are both hurt. Haven's ribs and chest are so bru that it is agony to take a breath. He knows it has to end quickly or he is done for, and he goes all out. As Mick t to close with him again, he stands his ground and throws  pile-driver punches to Mick's midsection; as Mick finally lowers his arms to cover his body, Haven shifts his attac to the face. This is not Mick's style of fighting, but as lashes back clumsily and angrily, each time he touches Ha it is with punishing power. Toe to toe, they slug it out, the belt now unwound and dangling from Mick's fist, both groggy but both refusing to go down. Finally Mick is help to protect himself, but Haven hasn't got power left to kn him off those sturdy legs. Gathering himself, Haven hurls his body shoulder first at Mick's chest but he miscalcula glances off and falls flat on his face. As he rolls over, dogged and slow with exhaustion, he sees that his weight staggered Mick; the big man has taken a step back, and no he starts to walk forward. Dazed and blind with pain, he  passes Haven, staggers forward until the tie-rail stops h There he stands, his hands on the rail, moving his head f side to side like a wounded animal. The crowd is silent now, waiting. Haven gets to his feet, drunk with weariness. He puts a hand on Mick's shoulder, hasn't the strength to whirl him around. He braces himsel with one hand against the tie-rail, and almost in slow mo pulls Mick around and clips him one last time with his  remaining strength. Mick goes down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up very slow) You can't do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before he is up he goes down again, unable to make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in the dirt) Nobody can do this... to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd is transfixed. They can't even cheer. The two  bouncers lean over the fallen Mick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody just did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pick up Mick as Haven stupidly watches. Then as Have turns and goes away, swaying and weak, the roar rises. He pushes aside people who try to assist him. They move asid and watch him leave. The crowd goes back in the saloon be the vanquished Mick... ANGLE on Charlie, Bristow and Prince. Prince watches the  beaten Mick go by with a smile of contempt. Charlie's eye are fixed on the vanishing lonely figure of Haven. Mark's eyes are dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it. Mick Marion losing  a fight and me winning a thousand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Prince) Give it to him, Prince -- in chips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bristow follows Prince, wiping his forehead. Charlie rema looking down the now empty street where Haven vanished, a strange soft look in her eyes, a slow smile mounting her  lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orville behind his desk is strumming softly on the guitar his eyes following Haven as the latter slowly and somewha painfully walks in and across the lobby. All the way to t desk the clerk watches Haven, strumming softly. Haven pau and smiles very faintly at him. The clerk puts the guitar aside. There is a coffee pot and cup on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning on the desk) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orville pours it quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning back to pick  up a pitcher and a  bottle) They told me who was fightin'. I was  getting ready to rent your room.  Cream or sugar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orville pours the "cream" from a whiskey bottle. Haven si gingerly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking with mild  curiosity and  admiration) Myself, I'd rather fight a forest  fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) So would I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finishes the coffee, turns and starts for his room. Or tosses two towels on Haven's shoulder as the latter goes. Strumming the guitar again softly, he watches with admira the retreating form of Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven stands in the darkness only lighted by lights of th saloon next door. He stands there looking vaguely out the window, sucking his knuckles absently as he listens to th piano playing. Then he goes wearily to the bed and falls it gratefully, shutting his eyes, the towels still across his shoulder. There is a moment of silence and then a sof KNOCK at the door. Another KNOCK, and painfully Haven lif himself on one elbow and drags out his gun. The door open and Charlie enters. She shuts it behind her and stands lo at him. He lets the gun fall and turns over on his back.  Charlie walks across to the bed and stands looking down a him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just cost me a thousand. You  lost your pipe in the fight. I brought  it to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts it on the table beside the bed. Haven's eyes fol her. She sees the towels, takes them to the washstand, so them and brings them back and compresses them gently on  Haven's bruised face. When she takes the towel away, he p himself up a little, propped against the pillow, looking her curiously. She sits down on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you always get sweet with the men  who fight over you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only the winners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches her as she wets the towels again, returns and  wraps his hands in them, sitting again on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, smiling) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he lies back) That fellow might have killed me -- (sleepily) Where do you bury the losers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is almost asleep. She takes the now unused towel and p it back in the basin, soaks it, returns with it and tucks against the side of his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talk too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) What do you want -- the next dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'd better sit this one  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is sound asleep the next second. She stares at him; ri puts the blanket over him and goes quietly out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven comes to the desk from his room. Orville is singing another verse of the ballad. The clerk favors Haven with admiring smile. The coffee pot is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orville strums the strings as Haven drinks, having a litt trouble with his sore hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way you run this dump I knew you  must be good at something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some call me the town poet -- and  some the village idiot. Who am I to  question either? How you feel today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I crawled here from Kansas City.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it figures to make you pretty  famous. Fact, people been askin' for  you already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That gold mine lady -- Mrs. Caslon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't do better. And Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Charlie owns a piece of  everything, includin' the undertaker  and the sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stage line too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything but the Wednesday Bible  Class. Even owns a piece of me. (grins) Takes your money while you're here,  and makes you pay to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting down the cup) When you get the next verse I'd like  to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't find no word to rhyme with  Mick Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he turns away) Carrion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks off. Orville ponders this, scowling into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iles is pacing the floor. Mrs. Caslon is occupied with so minor domestic chore. Stellman is standing by the door. I is a ball of fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of all the stupid bonehead plays!  What did he fight about -- don't  tell me a woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what they tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who started it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, but Haven finished it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That probably strikes you as a very  admirable thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stellman shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't think so! I have men  who can use their fists. Why didn't  they send a man who could use his  brains!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock at the door. Iles gives her a look; then glares at Stellman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- open it up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stellman opens the door and Haven walks in. He pauses, gl around and smiles. Mrs. Caslon smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mrs. Caslon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles and nods. Irons. Haven can feel the surcharged air. Deliberately he assumes that casual manner that so b the Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain... Lieutenant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) Mr. Haven, we may not have very much  around here that pleases you, but we  do have a strict post regulation  against brawling in the town. Now  would you like to explain what  happened last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) I came here to return Mrs. Caslon's  call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iles glances sharply at Mrs. Caslon, and then to Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating a chair) Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven sits, wincing a little. But he beams at Iles, who n picks a book off the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This book I have in my hand is the  Army Register, 1882.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven inspects his knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am now going to read from it. (finds the place;  reads) "Haven, John Martin, born Ohio 1852.  Appointed Second Lieutenant. Promoted  First Lieutenant 20th Infantry, March  1880; reduced in rank to 2nd  Lieutenant January 12, 1881."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses the book on the table, glaring at Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Army Register.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven, you've lost your rank once.  It may very well happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To almost anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe if you'd let him explain... He  might have a good reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even a bad reason would delight me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you like to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you pick that fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those things can become very vague.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iles scowls to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrewdly) And where do you expect all this to  get you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising wearily) That is a question I prefer not to  answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snaps it) I think you're trying to carry your  authority too far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven goes to the door, gently touching his sore jaw. At door he turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps, but there's one thing,  Captain Iles... We had an arrangement  that we wouldn't meet -- you and I -- except through Mrs. Caslon... I think  it's important to keep it that way... (one more glance back) And I like it better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles and leaves, closing the door as he goes. Iles s there frozen with rage a moment. Then his face relaxes in grim smile. He glances at Stellman as he takes a cigar ou and bites it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business is slack. Girls drink coffee and knit at a table Ernie polishes glasses at the bar. A colored man cleans a crap table. All look up with curiosity and esteem as Have enters; all but Sam, the piano player, who goes on playin Haven goes to the bar. Ernie nods at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't he ever stop playing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam? It don't bother him. He's deaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do I find the boss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First door top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mick been around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's undisposed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven goes to the stairs. The eyes of the girls follow hi Top of the stairs -- as Haven reaches the door, wincing a the climb. He KNOCKS with the heel of his hand, hurts it, then uses his boot toe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a big corner room, the windows of which look out  over the main street. The chairs are big and there is a r top desk in the corner, a big leather sofa, and on the wa some framed pictures. At a table Prince sits. He has six  dice stacked on top of each other and he is lifting the  column. Charlie is seated behind the desk smiling. Haven  looks from one to the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Prince) You wanted to see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said Charlie --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She seems to enjoy Haven's momentary confusion. Prince is indifferent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. (nods toward Prince) This is Prince. Don't ever gamble  with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean with his equipment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince gives him a thin smile and rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She means either. (he crosses to door) See you later, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince saunters out. Haven sits in a big chair, very gingerly; takes out his p and tobacco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You surround yourself with very  affable characters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes me feel at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not that sinister. Last night  with the wet towels you were Florence  Nightingale in silk stockings. (stretching his legs,  looking at her) Have you got a match?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes over with one and lights his pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's one in my pocket but I hate  to reach for it... thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes his hand and looks at the cut knuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks out of the room and he watches her; then around the room. In a moment she returns, pulls up a chair in th front of him and sits down. She has bandages and a little jar of ointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Now you're Florence Nightingale again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes one of his bruised hands, and as she bandages h hands slowly, carefully and rather expertly, they talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you pick that fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have insisted I was your  cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps that isn't the way I felt  about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as his knuckle hurts) Ouch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles at him and then goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get the name of Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was my father's. My name is  Charlene, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like that better... Charlene... (she doesn't answer) This'll be the first time I ever  worked for a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving him a glance) What makes you think you're going to  work for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sent for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finishing the bandage) How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands up. Haven looks at her and ignores his bandage hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking towards the  window) All right, I sent for you. I was  doing a nice quiet business. That  was because everybody was afraid of  Mick. Now every time a man has enough  drinks in him to feel rugged he'll  try to do what you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the job I want. I don't  intend to start at the bottom. I've  been there. It's too crowded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly) Where do you want to start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what will you do for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything -- except hang. How did you  get -- all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I learned one thing from my father.  As long as men think they can beat  the tables, all you have to do is  get a table. Sometimes they run out  of cash and I find myself with new  responsibilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of stores for one thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't see myself behind a counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sawmill, and a logging camp. The  logging camp's a long way from town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven gets the meaning and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I own the stage line from here to  West Rim City, but that's a dud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outlaws. The money was in gold  shipments. Now the mines won't ship  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take that job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean ride shot-gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean run the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't force your luck. You won a  fight last night. You could lose one  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today I'd hate to tangle with a  butterfly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think you'll get out of  running the stage line?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A commission on all the gold I get  through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That should buy you a small beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pretty dangerous. Even Wells  Fargo locked up their station and  quit trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leveling) Who steals the gold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who doesn't? All they have to do is  put a mask on and they all look like  Black Bart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) Give me a letter of authorization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going to the desk) I can't bet against you twice, can  I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she writes out the authorization, Haven saunters to th window, then over to the desk. Charlie finishes and hands him the paper. Haven scans it, pockets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling at him) You know I forgot to ask you one  thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm working for you now. You can ask  me anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven is moving to the door and she beside him. They paus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I know I can trust you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her face, neck and hair. She looks pretty goo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only with money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven looks squarely at her a moment, then smiles. He rea out one bandaged hand and pats her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Okay, boss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks out, and Charlie remains standing there, staring after him, just a little hazily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven walks through the wide gate into a compound. The are several unhitched stages and freight wagons, one or t in partial disassembly and being serviced. A colored boy readying a horse and buggy and beside him, overlooking th yard activities, is a bespectacled man with rubber sleeve garters. He is the manager. He has eyes like Armadillo an claw-like hands; otherwise, he could be your loan agency  man. Seeing Haven he crosses to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking him over) Are you the manager?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard about you. You're the  fellah who took Mick Marion apart. (looking at him) Almost knocked me off my feet. But  my feet ain't been any good since I  followed Stonewall Jackson. (keenly) What business you got with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him the note) I'm the new boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manager glances at the note, after moving his spectac out of the way. He gives it back without a word, and turn toward the rear office door. Haven halts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. You're not fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to be. There ain't enough work  around here for one man, let alone  two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two can loaf as easy as one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim Goddard and Jerry enter from the rear office door. Je is the younger. Goddard walks a little stiffly with the a of a cane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Leonard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They halt and look at Haven. The Manager jerks a thumb at Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to him. He just took the reins. (indicating the two  lads) This is Jim Goddard. He's a regular  stage driver. Jerry here runs freight  to the sawmill. Boys, your new boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a grin of hero  worship) I gotta start out of here for the  sawmill before daybreak. Is that all  right, Mr. Haven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven nods, after a glance at the manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seen that fight last night. It was  sure a beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad you enjoyed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I liked was the way you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not talk about it. Right now  it hurts my hands to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks out, looking back with an awesome smile. Haven l curiously at Goddard, who has been standing in silence, a thin smile on his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My last run. I stopped a bullet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get a look at them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm going to need you and  not on one leg. So sit down and give  it a rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly smiling) Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He obeys. Haven watches and then turns to the manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm coming back later and sit behind  your desk. I'll need the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking keys from his  pocket) Only things here that work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manager, gives them to him. Then looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, I waste my time. I might as  well waste some advice. You're full  of blood and vinegar, but this whole  thing has got something wrong with  it. Goddard only got nicked in the  shin. You might not be so lucky...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might depend on something besides  luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like for instance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well the fact that they don't seem  to shoot too straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't need to when they shoot  so often.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, takes a few steps -- and turns back to Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worry it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manager turns to go, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven, whistling softly, crosses to the colored boy who i polishing the last specks of dust off the buggy. It is a  beautiful buggy attached to a beautiful horse. Haven paus and gazes at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The colored boy steps back and admires his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sumpin', ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's it for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Charlie, Mr. Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you drive her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same places. Around the hills, down  the river, every afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll give you this afternoon  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't let you do this, suh... (looking Haven over,  especially the  bandaged hands) But ah am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven climbs in the buggy, and the Colored Boy watches hi go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is dressed to go somewhere. She looks much nicer these clothes than in her show garments of the night. She listening to Prince who sits in a chair, the inevitable d in his fingers, two this time. There is a silence except rattle of the cubes. Then Prince speaks coldly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this Haven move me out? Is that  the plan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince, you know I wouldn't part  with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I always come up empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quite empty. I gave you what is  probably the one honest feeling you  ever had in your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep forgetting that. Pardon me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Prince?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like John Haven or anything  about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to have him looked up in  the Social Register?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up, goes to the window testily. Prince looks at coldly as she gazes at the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man walks in out of nowhere --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning) And went against your table. Did he  play like a gambler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knew something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- and he took Mick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he can fight. (shrewdly) You like that part, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks straight at her and she stares back, staring him down at last. As his eyes lower, she turns again to the  window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you one thing, Prince, I  don't like this part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is silent and Prince gets up and walks out. She does turn. Down in the street she can see Haven riding up in t buggy, and the hard look on her face softens to a smile a Haven climbs out of the buggy. Some people passing stare him, and whisper together. His fame has spread. He walks  inside, smiling a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven enters. There is no play at the tables. Some at bar. The deaf pianist is pounding the keys softly. Prince has just descended the stairs and gone to the dice table, where he leans, his cold eyes fixed on Haven as the latte goes to the foot of the stairs. At this moment Charlie ap and descends the stairs, adjusting her hat. Haven stares her with admiration, as she descends, smiling at him. MED. SHOT - Haven and Charlie, as she reaches the last st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand there a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time I see you, you look  different, but you always look  beautiful. Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always have somebody to lie to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take my hand -- (offering it) But don't squeeze it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes his arm instead and they walk towards the door. MOVING SHOT - Charlie and Haven, as they go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what you're doing with my  buggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My work. I'm the new transportation  boss. You hired me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT of Prince, as he stands at the table, watching  them go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven helps Charlie into the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I presume you're going shopping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't wear anything sold this  side of Chicago. I'm going to call  on a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this hour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name is Mark Bristow -- and any  hour, it would be strictly business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way you say it -- he may need a  lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a lawyer himself, but it won't  help him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile) What good is a lawyer if he never  gets in a court?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a doctor in a graveyard. Where  is this unlucky man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven shrugs and turns the carriage to front of Bristo office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The letters on the window read: Mark Bristow, Lawyer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven pulls up in front of it with the carriage. He go around and helps Charlie alight, making it a little slow the sake of added intimacy and causing her to smile as th she didn't resent it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I take the horses back and rub  them down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think they've gone far enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then maybe you better wait and come  with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Charlie starts in, Mrs. Caslon comes out and they pass Mrs. Caslon pauses to smile and Haven tips his hat. Charl flashing a backward look, sees this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT of Haven and Mrs. Caslon. Haven is talking to h with apparent casualness because he realizes that Charlie can see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if you'd do me a favor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, surely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a big favor, and I wouldn't  blame you if you refused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to haul some gold from your  mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That IS a big favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it seems impossible to you,  but that's one reason why I'm here --  to find cut what makes it impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that very risky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I couldn't go to anyone  but you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitating) I'm just wondering if we shouldn't  speak to Captain Iles first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what he'd say. (she smiles grimly  and nods) He'd advise against it -- but if it  works my way, it may clear everything  up -- for all of us -- and for Iles  too. The War Department doesn't like  all that gold around an Army Post.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches her face as she thinks it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) We're working too much in the dark.  This may be the only way to see  something. It's a risk -- but someone  has to take it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly) Who else will know of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just us. That'll be all who know --  and that's the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) I'll arrange it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Don't look so grim. It's only your  gold and my skin. And smile when you  walk away as though we'd been talking  about what a dry summer it's been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles and Haven pats her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bristow is talking. Charlie, looking through the windo sees Haven and Mrs. Caslon part, Haven patting her should with that familiar gesture of his, then coming into the o door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You know I'll always cooperate --  as much as possible. But I haven't  the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven has entered in silence, seated himself in a chair.  Charlie does not look at him; her face, hard now, looks  straight at Bristow. He pauses as he glances at Haven wit little nod Haven doesn't return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising and going to  the desk with a sheaf  of papers, which she  places on his desk) These are I.O.U.s for gambling. They  add up to six thousand dollars. Do  you want to count them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (returning them to  her pocket) Your credit's over, Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My luck can turn, can't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not on my tables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen other people fall in this  trap -- but I didn't think it would  get me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is sweating a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody does. I'll have Prince drop  in and go over your books. Maybe we  can work something out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I told you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way it is, Mark. I pay  off on the line and I expect to get  paid. Give it some thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She whirls and walks out the door. Haven, fumbling for hi pipe and putting it in his teeth, follows her with a part glance at Bristow. For a long minute Bristow sits there a his eyes staring at nothing; then as he mops the mildew o sweat from his forehead:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Charlie and Haven drive in the country. The road winds between hills now and a stream tumbles along beside the  winding road. The horse is moving at a snail's pace and  Charlie is gazing around at the scenery, relaxed and  thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you remind me a little --  back there -- of a character I once  read in a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had an idea you'd read a book.  What was the character?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon Legree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark is mixed up. He's either crooked  without being smart, or honest without  being lucky. And that's no good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I'd want to owe you  money -- even if I was honest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was seven I robbed my own  piggy bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to imagine you being seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was very fat and ate a lot of candy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that why you robbed your bank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I robbed it to run away from  home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I had to go back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It got dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs. They stop and get out.

dialogues.speaker: STREAM BANK
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT as Haven helps her down the bank to the edge of the water. She sits on the edge of a huge flat boulder an Haven stretches out beside her. MED. SHOT of Haven and Charlie. As she looks at the strea and then at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my favorite place in the  world... I always come here to think  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rook here and the stream. The  stream is always running away and  the rock is always watching it go.  It's two ways to be -- and I always  wonder which is the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They probably envy each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you suppose any woman could envy  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not a good woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody is any good. You mean  respectable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
