dialogues.text: Respectable people are very useful --  but they bore me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With certain exceptions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curiously) Like who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like Mary Caslon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we might get to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you happen to know her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew her husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's curious, considering --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Considering what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben Caslon was a very upright citizen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning I'm not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (adds thoughtfully) She's certainly not hard to look at --  and now she has the money and is -- (looking away) -- also very respectable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why would she be interested in  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're no good. And good  women like men who are bad for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flattery will get you nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fooling with her will get you nowhere  too -- except in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With whom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The army. Why is it you're always  getting mixed up with the army?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven has been idly flipping pebbles into the stream. He  sees a leaf float by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (idly) What are the odds I hit the leaf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (absently) Four to one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pass -- (he flips the pebble,  misses) What's the army got to do with Mrs.  Caslon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's engaged to Captain Iles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the army boss here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) If you're going to frighten me, the  least you can do is hold my hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out his hand and takes hers. Abruptly she starts rise, very piqued and unable to disguise it. Haven rises  too. Takes her hand to help her from the boulder. Then st and gazes at her, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where you ought to slip --  and I should catch you and kiss you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts down; Haven moves too, but it is he who slips she who has to catch him. Her arms go automatically aroun him. His around her. Before he can act himself, she holds him tight and kisses him. It is a long kiss and on it we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orville is strumming the guitar as Haven enters. He pause as Haven comes near on the way to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven halts, walks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You finish that song?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my fatality. I never finish  nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's just as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe so. I thought I'd tell you.  Goin' back to your room will be a  waste of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what happened on that  buggy ride, but somebody came and  took all your truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strums the strings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, naturally, you didn't do anything  about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What could I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have called the sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set a thief to catch a thief, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I paid my rent and I think I'm  entitled to know who stole my clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after him) A man couldn't ask for no prettier  thief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven enters, glances around, sees the bag is missing. He goes to the window, sees Charlie at saloon window across areaway. He leans out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie moves the window, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning out) Hello... I've been wondering where  you were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost my shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't imagine that I'd let you  live in that hotel, did you? I want  you available -- in case of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did I move?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a very nice room upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking out his pipe) When can you get my things back to  the hotel, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at him, the smile fading on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you take them yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) Because that's not how they got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slight pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're really hard -- aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to play everything alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This hotel is no good. The service  is bad. The clerk's a poet, and the  mattress is not quite as soft as a  marble slab. But I'm beginning to  like it... and if I open this window,  and hear you singing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the way you want it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns abruptly from the window. Haven smiles and turn away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven is finishing preparations for the ride. ANGLE ON Go as he stands in shadow, watching. He carries a shotgun. A Goddard moves from the shadow, Haven whirls, going for hi gun -- then relaxing as he recognizes the other man. MED. SHOT of Haven and Goddard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What brings you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) I had a dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you'd be back here tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe because you took the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't they go with the job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven stares at him a long moment; Goddard returns the st steadily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how it is with dreams. I  got the crazy idea you were going to  try something --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like running a shipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to be some help with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- you've been some help.  Now you can go back to sleep and  I'll finish the dream for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coach is ready. Goddard doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm riding with you, Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) I'm riding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) You got more than your leg hurt,  didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I just like to ride in the  moonlight if nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if it does?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I think I got a little better  right than you to be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gazing at him) I was just thinking -- a nice guy  like you probably has a nice girl  somewhere -- or a wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we gonna do -- have a little  chat about women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven slowly grins at him; Goddard smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some other time -- Let's go -- out  the back gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddard climbs up with his shotgun as Haven clambers up i the driver's seat. As the coach turns and heads for the b of the corral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT - the stagecoach, travelling across open flat  country, heading toward the distant hills. CLOSE SHOT - Haven and Goddard in the driver's box, keepi an eye about him as the teams gallop along in the moonlig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you so anxious to take  this chance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on commission. With me it's a  matter of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you think it's something else  with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't think of anything else --  except curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gazing out drily) Some moonlight after all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT as the stage rockets off into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stage is now heading uphill, the gentle slope at the  beginning of the foothills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road is steeper now, and winding. ANOTHER ANGLE. The road is cut out of the side of the  mountain, leaving a sheer slope on one side, and high, th trees and brush on the other. As the stage follows a bend the road, a rider leaps out and grabs the lead horse. The stage lurches crazily and almost overturns as it slows to stop. Before Haven can free his hands from the reins to g for his gun, two shadowy figures, handkerchiefs helping t darkness mask their faces, have jumped out onto the road  ahead and have him covered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- stretch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven and Goddard raise their arms. Another bandit, from hillside, calls out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pile out with the hands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two shotgun barrels cover the side of the stags. Goddard  gets off, hands in air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Haven) Get down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven obeys, to join Goddard in the road, as the bandits  converge on the stage. There are five or six of them. Two come up behind Haven and Goddard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn around and keep 'em high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sacks are being loaded on a pack horse. Haven turns  around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy. They hang you just the  same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, Goddard, start walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives Goddard a none too gentle shove. Goddard moves o up the road in the darkness. A FEW YARDS UP THE ROAD. Mick is waiting by his horse, hi gun drawn. We hear the steps of Goddard and the bandit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's far enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The footsteps halt. Mick aims and fires. BY WAGON. There is a half grunt, half groan from Goddard. Haven turns as if to protest and then crumples as a gun f him. CLOSE SHOT - Haven, lying face down on the ground,  unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As day breaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - Haven. Haven comes to, gradually clearing th cobwebs. Then suddenly he remembers Goddard and the shot. makes his way to where Goddard's body lies a few feet up road. Goddard's right hand is half in his hip pocket, as in his last dying moment he was reaching for something. A Haven pulls the hand out, he sees that Goddard's fingers  have closed around his wallet. Puzzled, Haven opens the  wallet. There is a stiff-backed daguerreotype of his wife an expired Union Pacific Railroad pass, an express receip a souvenir bank-note of the Confederacy, and a small, clo folded piece of paper. Unfolding this, Haven sees the top line: "To Whom It May Concern"

dialogues.speaker: HE READS FURTHER
dialogues.text: "This certifies that the bearer, James Goddard, is operat as a legally deputized detective for Wells Fargo Stage an Express Company." Haven replaces the papers and lifts Goddard's body, carri it to the stage and places it on the floor. He removes  Goddard's gun and shell belt and straps it on, closing th stage door. Haven's face is grim as he studies the ground nearby. The sticky mud shows clearly the new tracks of th bandits' horses. As he starts unhitching one of his horse from the wagon traces, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny clearing on a brush-filled knoll, where the remain of a cooking fire are still visible, the ashes scattered  over the tamped-down ground. CAMERA PANS OVER TO Haven, o horseback, as he studies the scene. This is where he evid made camp for the night. He dismounts, sifts the ashes th his fingers to feel their warmth. He cannot be far behind Then he turns his attention to the trail loading away.  Inspection reveals that it divides, one group of fresh tr heading towards town, another smaller group further into mountains. He decides to follow the latter. As he mounts rides off:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A high spot from which Haven can get a good view. Off in distance he sees: LONG SHOT - FROM his ANGLE. A lone rider, leading a pack  horse, barely visible through the timber. He is heading a from him. CLOSE SHOT - Haven. He spurs his horse forward. FULL SHOT - Haven, in pursuit of the man ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bandit, unaware of his pursuer, puts his horse and th gold-laden pack horse through the stream. He comes out in a meadow on the other side. PAN SHOT - WITH Haven, as he comes to the stream. Half wa across, his horse momentarily loses his footing on the  slippery rocks. MED. SHOT - bandit. Hearing the noise of Haven's horse, h turns and sees his pursuer, takes a quick shot back at hi then heads for the other side of the meadow where there w be shelter, firing back as he rides. MED. CLOSE SHOT - Haven. He takes careful and deliberate and fires. FULL SHOT - FROM Haven's ANGLE. The bandit is almost at t edge of the woods when Haven's shot gets him. He tumbles  from the saddle. Haven rides forward, gun ready in case i is a trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is no trick. The bandit is down where he fell. When Ha turns him over, the man's eyes are already glazed. Haven  puts his lips close to the dying man's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who sent you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man only glares up at him. Haven tries again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a goner, brother -- you can  talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man holds Haven's gaze defiantly and silently as the  life goes out of him. Haven lowers him back to the ground rifles his pocket. There are no papers on him, no  identification. He stands up. He has the gold back, but h is no closer to rounding up the whole gang than he was be Unless -- he is looking at the horses, placidly grazing. goes up to them, ties up the loose lead reins, draws his  belt off, and gives them each a sharp crack on the rump w the buckle. They take off across the meadow at a gallop.  Haven lets them get a good start before he mounts his own horse, and follows after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven rides up to the edge of a downslope, gazes over broad valley, and sees: LONG VIEW of a sawmill, nestled in the valley. It compris several sheds and buildings, with a long rank of stacked  logs beside the biggest shed, and all this is serviced by dirt road along which the two horses canter up to the cam Haven observes several men come out of the main office an snag the two horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As two men who have snagged the horses now take off the g bags. In front of the office Pete, the camp boss, Ben and Sam, two tough-looking accomplices, stand watching and  glancing up the road down which the horses came. There is frown on Pete's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Joe? (as Pete doesn't answer) Something's gone wrong, Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete looks thoughtfully at Joe's horse, pats his neck, ag locks up the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know one thing. He was born on a  horse and he didn't just fall off  this one... go and take a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two men mount and start away. CLOSE SHOT of Haven. As he moves back out of sight. Obvio he can't move into the camp now. Glancing off down the va he sees in the distance a work wagon approaching. It is s hidden from sight of the sawmill by high ground between. puts his horse down the slope towards the approaching wag at a tangent to the camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the work wagon lumbers along. Its markings identify it belonging to the stageline Haven now manages. We recogniz Jerry the driver as Haven rides up. Jerry gives him a gri and a salute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello there, Mr. Haven!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Jerry. What's the haul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is that load of grub for the  sawmill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to ride my horse back to town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the wagon here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll finish the haul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He climbs down as Haven dismounts and turns the horse ove to Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing it away) Any excitement in town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) Don't know, Mr. Haven. I left before  daybreak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved) Take him easy. He's tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give him a good rubdown. (mounting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven watches him ride away, then climbs aboard the wagon Picking up the reins, he notices the bandages on his hand and, not wanting to be identified by them, rips them off. Blowing on his still sore knuckles, he drives toward the  sawmill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven's wagon lumbers in. He looks curiously at the ma office. No one is in sight, but as he draws nearer, the  swarthy hard-faced man, Pete, comes out on to the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see a rider comin' up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't even seen a lizard. Where do  I put this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you put it before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never did. I'm a new driver. I  think it's grub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it to the cook shack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven flicks the reins, moves on. Pete watches suspicious Haven moves on to the cook shack outside of which the coo is busy dumping a pail of slop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling up) You the cook?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah. I just wear this hat to keep  the flies out of my hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It don't matter to me, brother. I  just haul this grub. I'd just as  soon haul it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it next door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven pulls up by the warehouse next door and gets down.  There is nobody around, so he starts wrestling with the f crates himself, taking the first one into the warehouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is big, barnlike, piled with provisions and equipment. Haven stares around; carries the crate to where a similar stack of crates are piled. Lowering the crate he notes a  shiny object, picks it up. It is a button from an army  uniform. He pockets it as his attention is distracted by horsemen passing outside. Haven goes out to continue  unloading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the two horsemen ride up to Pete and dismount. Ben and Sam are standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the horsemen) Any luck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sign of Joe. But there's the tracks  of another horse, circling the mill  and coming back on the road just  north. (he points)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances toward the wagon where Haven is working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go and look at this guy again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The five men move down to Haven's wagon. ANGLE ON wagon and Haven, as he sees them come. His lip  tightens; then he relaxes and goes on lifting a crate. He pauses as they come up and stand around him, their eyes f on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you didn't see no rider?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look -- you want me to say I saw a  rider? I'll say it. I'll say I saw a  ghost. It don't make any difference  to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you get this job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the system. If I don't work I  don't eat. I never been able to find  any way to beat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who hired you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blandly) Mr. Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy that had the fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a risky little moment; Haven eases both bruised han into his coat pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (innocently) Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any man who gives me a job is my  friend. Look, I'm working, I haul  this stuff out here. Nobody wants to  tell me where to dump it. Everybody  wants to know what I'm doin' and  what I haven't seen. I don't know. I  get thirty cents an hour. How smart  does that have to make me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete's face relaxes; as do the grim faces of the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) I ain't hot. I'm just mixed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. I got a load for you to  take back when you're done here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I haven't eaten anything but  dust since sun-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- grab it quick. (to the others) Work on this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start unloading and Haven goes to the cook house. Pe watches him go. Ben notes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We risk him, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't look right to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't look any worse than the  rest of it looks right now. (turning) Come on, get this junk out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lends a hand with Ben and Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big pot of stew is simmering on the fire. The cook is b slicing french fries. Haven enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a handout?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven begins ladling out some stew into a bowl, tastes it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cook pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ought to. I used to cook for six  hundred men a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leavenworth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven shrugs and takes more stew; the cook goes on cuttin the potatoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This used to be my mother's special  dish. She made it right out of the  world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My old woman couldn't boil a potato.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven takes another gulp in the silence that follows. The he says carelessly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's boss around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean the whole works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talked to the man when you came  in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real tough-looking fellah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spits) They're all tough till they get to  Mick Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mick come out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night -- and he looked like  somebody got to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Face all beat up -- (casually) Like your knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had bad luck with a crate of  cauliflower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what he brought down here --  a cauliflower face. (casually) You fight him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling blandly) Mick? Do I look like I would?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at him) Just the knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben's head appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry it up, driver!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven takes a last mouthful, turns toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not many of the hands here, are there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All up at the logging camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much obliged. That was real fine  mulligan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cook isn't interested; he spits as he slices a potato

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete, Sam and Ben are waiting beside the gear box as we s Haven bringing the wagon up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe this isn't such a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said it was? I just want that  gold outa here the easiest and  quickest way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They watch Haven as he pulls up the wagon. Pete looks har at his face. Haven has the pipe in his mouth again, looki very blandly at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see this box?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It goes to Prince. Know who Prince  is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs things for Charlie. Know who  Charlie is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven climbs aboard. They look hard at him. He has stuck pipe in his mouth. He smiles at them and he picks up the  reins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a gear box you're hauling  back and it's got to be repaired.  And you tell Charlie that if it ain't  repaired we might have to shut down  quick. You got that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- then get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven flicks the reins, grins at them and drives off. Ben still worried and stares after the departing wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is deserted country on the way to town. When the lan slopes steeply from the road down into a kind of wash, Ha halts the wagon. He glances around. No sign of life. He t a hammer and chisel out of the tool box beside the seat,  crawls to the crate and prys it open. His cargo is gold.  Satisfied, he replaces the pried board, then pushes the c over the side. It topples down the bank, vanishes in the  brush at the bottom of the wash. With one more glance aro Haven resumes his seat in the wagon, puts a match to his  pipe, and sends the horses forward at a faster clip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iles is pacing up and down as Stellman enters quietly. Il promptly faces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- what have you found out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddard's body -- shot in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And no sign of Haven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One horse was missing. They might  have taken him away on that. They  wouldn't kidnap him if they'd killed  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would they kill Goddard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a Wells Fargo Detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see... he was a man they couldn't  handle, so they shot him. But Haven  wasn't killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He may have followed them on the  missing horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he may be fishing for trout in  the Verde River. Why do I always  learn everything last? Why must  everything be common gossip by the  time it reaches me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither do I, but I'll find out. The  Army didn't banish me out here to  set up a listening post. Bring the  man in, dead or alive. If he's alive,  arrest him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But can you arrest him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I can take any living human  being into custody -- or am I mistaken  in this too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then go and do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stellman turns and leaves obediently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOT FROM Haven's ANGLE to include street activity. As Ma approaches, opens the door and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mark enters in the semi-darkness and pauses, stiff wit fright at the sight of Haven sitting in the chair, a gun his hand. Mark opens his mouth but can't speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Draw those blinds, Bristow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Numbly, Mark obeys; then turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- light it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark lights the lamp. His voice is small and quavering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating gun) Can't you put that firearm away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can -- but it quiets my nerves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark pours a drink shakily from a decanter by his law lib

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark gulps his in an ominous silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd given you up for dead -- we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (idly rotating the  cylinders of the gun) Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, everybody. They found Goddard's  boy -- didn't you know that? What  happened? Tell me about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) I'm glad you got your voice back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're trying to imply that you  frightened me, coming here like this,  you're right. I'm neither a hero nor  a fool. (he sits down) (shrewdly) They killed Goddard -- Why didn't  they kill you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody must have wanted me saved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe a rainy day. (dryly) Only it might never rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven puts the gun away; rises, walks to the desk, pours drink for himself. Mark watches him shrewdly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (himself again) And what do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to make a statement, which  you will write and notarize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- except that you put it away  where it can't be stolen or tampered  with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a safe --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see you have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning you don't trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do -- but I don't think you trust  yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you want it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Caslon has a safe -- a nice fat  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I can arrange it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- here's the statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He saunters to the window -- glances through the crack of the shades. When he turns, he notes that Mark has paper a pencil ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I solemnly swear that on Thursday  last, about eleven p.m. the stagecoach  in which I was riding was held up by  five armed bandits. The gold I was  hauling was stolen and James Goddard,  the guard, was murdered in cold blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses, looks stonily at the face of Mark, who is star at him curiously and waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trailed the bandits, caught up  with one and -- killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stares in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it down. (as Mark obeys) I then followed the horses bearing  the gold to a sawmill --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mick is standing outside, holding the arm of Jerry as he  talks to the kid. Beside him stands Pete Yore's man, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure it was Haven you met?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't I know my own boss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving him a shove) Go in and get a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven finishes his statement. He is again at the windo glancing out. Perhaps he has seen the incident with Mick Jerry across the crowded street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...After I left there, I opened the  crate. The gold was in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns back into the room. Mark is looking at him with  puzzled wonder, his face drawn and tense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles slightly. The wonder leaves Mark's face. Urbane cunning replaces it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do about the gold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to the conclusion that I  finally had enough money to need a  lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark smiles thinly, licking his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (needing a drink again) Have you seen the sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard about him, and I still  came to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. Well, as a lawyer, my advice  would be --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't come here for advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm wondering what you get out of  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes me more valuable to somebody  alive than dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (levelly) Now I'm wondering what I get out of  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They been here lookin' for you, the  men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought they might.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told them you was out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was. I just came in the back way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven lights the pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You finish that song?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had her finished, but what good is  it? It was about your death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it a couple of days -- may be  you can still use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strolls back towards his room and CAMERA FOLLOWS him, strumming of the guitar again SOUNDING in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven shuts the door, pulls off his boots and gun belt, l on the bed and stares at the ceiling. His face is sad and looks tired. The MUSIC from the saloon comes over, Charli song... he closes his eyes and in a moment falls asleep..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As iles rides up. He is just about to enter, after  dismounting, when Mark Bristow comes out of the office. M smiles and nods at the officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) Any news about Haven in town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just saw Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abruptly) Alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark mounts his horse, drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Iles opens the door and enters. Mrs. Caslon is her usu cool self as she sits at her desk. Iles crosses to her an gives her a peck on the cheek as she fondly pats his hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just passed Bristow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring this) Why don't you sit down. You look  tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits in a comfortable chair, conscious of the fact tha she had ignored his reference to Bristow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you've heard the news. The  holdup and poor Jim Goddard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard it -- last, as usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delaying) Why don't you smoke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iles gives her a surly look, takes a cheroot out of his t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a match and  crossing to light  his cigar) I'm afraid you're going to be angry  with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puffing) Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gold Haven tried to run was from  the Argus, darling

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was? (then reacting) Yours!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iles is about to yell something at her, then holds himsel in check, while she wipes the spilled ashes from his unif In this interlude he changes to an icy man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't excite yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am very calm, and I calmly ask you  how you could allow that scoundrel  to transport gold from your mine  when --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man you call a scoundrel may be  dead at this moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he may be in town at this moment --  where, in fact, he is. (looks at her) How you could do this without telling  me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only did it for your sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MY sake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all, Mr. Haven represents the  U.S. Government.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you think I represent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, George, I was only trying  to help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (containing his fury) And while we're on the subject, who  does Mark Bristow represent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know perfectly well that he's my  lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know perfectly well he's a scoundrel  too. (rises) Is he also trying to help me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks to the door. She stands there frigidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the door, a ball  of cold fire) Thank you, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and fumbles with the knob, but he can't do it. H turns at last and walks meekly back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'd say that I lost my  head if I believed that I had one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kissing him fondly) It's my fault George. (turning) Mark left me something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to the desk and hands him the long legal envelo Iles takes it and stares at it. He starts to open it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to open it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To whom it may concern. That's what  it says here. (going on) Well, it may concern me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens it, looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands it to her. She reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) My business isn't jammed up enough --  so they send this harebrained demoted  lieutenant pry around in it... They  want to help me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes back the paper from her, thrusts a blank sheet i the envelope, tosses the envelope back on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George -- you're getting to be a  hard man to deal with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting to deal with some hard  men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iron-faced, he starts out, remembers again, softens again his will, comes back from the door and kisses her cheek a then leaves. CAMERA stays on Mrs. Caslon as she watches h go. She smiles slightly, puts the envelope in the safe, a then from it takes a six-gun, looks at it and begins dust it with her handkerchief as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You certainly are a careful man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to be. I live a careless life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven begins washing his face in the washbowl, and then  combing his hair and readjusting his somewhat rumpled shi Mark watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the deposition?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has it. It's in her safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We call on Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a little nervous sweat on Mark's hands; he wipes them on his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a dangerous play, Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if she doesn't believe you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she'll have to believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That deposition could be a lie. It  might not stand up in a court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. You're a lawyer and you're  not sure. Then how can she gamble on  it, either?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she's a gambler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she isn't. (ready to go) We're the gamblers, Mark. Lot's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little shaken and uncertain, Mark obeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven and Mark come out. They walk towards the saloon. People look at them curiously. Suddenly, down the street, the sheriff appears, approaching Haven slowly and ominous Sensing a gun fight, people vanish. Purely from instinct, Mark deserts Haven's side in a hurried walk towards the  saloon, eyeing both. Haven comes on leisurely. The sherif has stopped in his tracks and has his gun out. A woman  clutches her child to her skirt. Men stand stockstill,  watching. A crowd forms at the entrance to Charlie's. Hav walks slowly forward until he reaches the waiting sheriff He looks him over with a smile of contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're under arrest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pausing) For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the murder of James Goddard --  and robbery under arms!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually) I've heard about you. You don't appear  to understand the functions of your  office. (taking sheriff's gun  and breaking it open) You've missed the whole point of  your profession. (showing him) Even your gun isn't loaded. (Haven loads it as it  goes on) I suggest that you start all over  again, with this point in mind: the  duty of a peace officer is to arrest  the culprit of a crime -- not the  victim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven hands him back the now loaded gun and walks away to the saloon, leaving the sheriff standing there, a complet dumbfounded and bepuzzled man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is roaring. Haven enters, followed by Mark. The guy at the piano is playing as always. Haven and Mark go  slowly to the bar, eyes following them. The noise softens almost to silence, except the piano, Cowering, Mark stick close to Haven. At the dice table, Prince stares coldly, hands another ma the stick and walks away to the stairway, his eyes seekin Mick Marion who is also staring at Haven. Prince nods to  Mick as he goes. MED. SHOT at bar -- as Haven and Mark loan against it. Er is looking at him curiously; then towards Mick. Haven doe follow the glance, but Mark does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie gets them. Haven glances at the piano. Mick who had stood there has now vanished. Haven smiles. The drinks ar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gulping his drink) This is no good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bourbon is just as bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't like it. (taking another drink) I'm a nervous man. Something's going  to happen. I can feel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why don't we do something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're doing something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting for something to happen. (smiling at Mark)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark finishes off his second. A stickman comes up. Nudges Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie wants to see you. Upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mark) See?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stickman moves away. Mark looks at Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I go with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you make it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven turns away towards the stairs. Mark hesitates, bite his lip, swallows another drink and then grimly follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is behind her desk, as Haven walks in. Behind him sweating now, comes Mark. As the two are in the room the  door behind them slams shut. Mick is there with a gun. Pr moves slightly out of a shadow. Mark backs against a wall Charlie looks up from her fingernails. Haven smiles and  glances around. His eyes fix on Mick and the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you found the difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mick says nothing, his face a blank hatred. Haven sits do in a big chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like a board meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another door opens and Pete, the sawmill foreman, enters, stands silently. Haven glances at him, then at Charlie wh smiles thinly back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Mark) What's he doing with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I might need a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can realize how seldom legal  technicalities annoy you -- but I  have one that might. (taking out his pipe) Besides, he knows all about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a gear box I failed to deliver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know anything! I merely --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark relapses into a perspiring silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Mark is right. He doesn't know  anything. He just knows what I  dictated to him in a deposition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just a story. About a man who  got murdered, a thief who got shot,  and a gear box that got lost. Probably  nobody would believe it -- (glancing up) ...unless I got killed for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie stares at him a moment. Then she glances at Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go downstairs, Pete. Watch the  stairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Haven) Who else have you told?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one. Mark I had to have. He's a  witness and a notary. He makes it  stick. He stands it up in court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (always watching his  face) What keeps it from getting to a court?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's running a bluff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ran one on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mick burns in silence. Charlie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You brought your lawyer. Ask him if  this doesn't sound like blackmail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't think very clearly in the  presence of a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it doesn't bother you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) No, it doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you want is money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see how going to the law  will get it for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you did see how, I'd never get  there, would I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it boils down to this: we can  make a deal, and all be happy  together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as long as you always have  something on us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless you also have something on  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how would that be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I deliver the gold to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the gear box?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can even forget I looked inside.  So I stole a gear box... I'm still a  thief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is silent a moment. Haven lights his pipe. Charli looks at Mark, pale by the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Mark) What does he get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets even with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you lost your mind!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was all right when he lost his  money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right... I'll give him the  IOU's... when the gear box is  delivered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) You don't realize how important it  is when a piece of machinery breaks  down. It could close the entire  sawmill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I didn't realize it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks coolly at Mick and Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark glances at Haven who nods and Mark leaves in the wak of the grimly departing Mick. Prince lingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Haven) You can stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Prince) I think she was talking to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince gets up grimly, his lips tight, the dice held hard his fingers. He stares at Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You roll nice dice and you bet them  jamb up, but some day you'll slip.  And when you do, I'll be around to  catch you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks out. Haven watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I think he will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you should be more careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poorhouses are filled with careful  men... (knocking out his  pipe) ...And so are the graveyards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie comes around and sits on the arm of his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a nice perfume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carnation. (she ruffles his hair  with her hand) I almost had to have you killed. I'd  have hated it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So would I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd have missed you... too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She brushes his cheek with her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she smiles at him) Did you ever tell a woman you loved  her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you get away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was always in the doorway when I  said it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never said it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go over to the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises and so does she. She picks up a scarf in silence and anger, crosses and goes out the door, Haven following her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven and Charlie descend. Her face is hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seem to always end up like this  with you. I take you for granted.  You like it that way. It goes with  loaded dice and crimped cards and  fixed wheels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they descend, Stellman can be seen in the bar crowd,  watching them. MED. SHOT of Charlie and Haven at foot of stairs. Haven i smiling at her, but her face is serious and her eyes hard

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me once you might be a  missionary on your way to China. And  that's as much as I've ever found  out about you. You're working for  me, but for all I know you could be  working for somebody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like Goddard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven smiles. He can see Stellman approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I better bring you that gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts away, but Stellman halts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven looks at him. Charlie watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me you're still recruiting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we still want you. But this is  a little different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Iles has asked me to take  you into custody, Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven stares at him, then looks at Charlie. A slow smile  dawns on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) You heard the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best thing for you is to come along,  Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I like -- the best thing  for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pats Charlie's shoulder and then walks out with Stellm Charlie watches them go. Prince appears beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very friendly with everybody -- isn't  he? Wells Fargo detectives, and now  the Army. How far can he go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly where he's headed now -- to  jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks away towards the piano. Prince stands there,  watching Haven go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Note: Pick up two night exteriors of the post.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a sergeant inside facing Iles who sits behind hi desk. Stellman and Haven pause at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Iles) The Quartermaster at Platte wants  three sworn statements before he'll  replace those seventy uniforms, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three sworn statements! I told him  all I know. They were in the freight  office at West Rim City. The building  burned down.. .you sure he doesn't  want me to send him the ashes too? (seeing Stellman) All right, have Stamm fix the papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sergeant exits. Iles looks calmly and with relish at  Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven and Stellman enter. Stellman closes the door and st near it. Haven smiles and nods at Iles, then sits down  unbidden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to see you alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dumb luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem to have been living quite  an adventurous life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that why I'm under arrest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's indefinite. I wanted to talk  to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you consult the Army Blue Book it  might enable you to be more definite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) Curiously enough, you got me into  the habit of reading myself. You're  quite right about The Blue Book -- (fiercely) UNLESS that officer should get himself  about one-half as far out of line as  you have!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iles picks up the deposition, extends it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here in your own statement!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven glances at him, then at the statement, and then tos it on the desk and inhales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you did what I expected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've gotten a man killed and Mrs.  Caslon's gold stolen. Is that far  enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising slowly) Haven -- as far as I'm concerned,  this deposition is good enough for  me. (indicates the  deposition) I want these people arrested. This  is all the evidence we need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what reason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the reason I came here... to get  the murderers of two soldiers -- not  to save somebody's gold. That's a  mistake you made. I still don't know  who killed them, but I'm going to  find out. And when the net is hauled  in, they're all going to be in it. (rising) That's my fish -- and you can have  the minnows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (demandingly) When are you returning Mrs. Caslon's  gold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly) That's a matter between myself and  Mrs. Caslon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look hard at each other in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't particularly like you -- but  I see no reason why you should get  yourself deliberately killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling again) It won't be deliberate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What difference does it make how you  get killed? Where does it leave me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does it leave me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meaning it) Understand this, Haven. You're heading  for bad trouble -- and when it comes  don't expect any help from me. Is  that clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling thinly) From the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven turns and walks out; the door closes behind him. Il slumps down into his chair. Stellman is smiling faintly a him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glumly) Yes, three cigars, a pint of whiskey,  and a copy of that confounded Blue  Book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stellman turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven saunters in. Orville is, as always, behind the d Haven nods at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the good word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you it's not good. You're in bad  trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how you can know so  much and move so little. (turning to go) I think I'll try it myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to leave a call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very nice of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you're sure everybody in town  is in bed -- call me. And if anybody  asks for me -- I went to jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes and Orville strums a little jail song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven, driving a wagon and team of horses, is retracing t road he took back from the sawmill looking for the place  where he dumped the bullion. CLOSER VIEW of Haven, as he looks for the landmarks. He i whistling softly the tune that Charlie always sings. At l he stops, alights and makes his way down the steep slope, couple of gunny sacks slung across his shoulder. Bottom of the gulley as Haven gets there and locates the  crate at rest in a clump of brush. The crate has broken f the fall. Haven loads the buckskin bags of gold into the  gunny sack and scrambles back up the slope. Side of slope as Haven scrambles to the top, he finds him looking into a six-shooter held in the unwavering hand of Mrs. Caslon. Her eyes are hard and a grim smile plays at corners of her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven obeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn around with your hands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven turns. She takes his gun and tosses it in the wagon then glances inside the sack, sees the gold. She backs of step or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- put it in the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven turns to obey. He manages a smile at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a hold-up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to put it in the wagon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at her hard  eyes) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He struggles with the sack, swings it onto the wagon in w he came. Then stands back, looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now was there something you wanted  to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trailed one of the bandits here  where they cached it. I couldn't  haul it on horseback, so I came here  with the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that's a lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of it's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not nearly enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try it again. I cached it here  myself. I was going to turn it over  to them. I wanted to buy a membership  in their club. This was the initiation  fee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty thousand dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you see, I thought it was worth  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you see, I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She climbs to the seat of the wagon watching him warily.  Haven doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) What you're doing may get me into  serious trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're still in town in twenty- four hours, I promise what I do may  get you hanged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs the rein of her own horse, flicks the reins of wagon team and rides away, leaving Haven on the road,  horseless and very much discountenanced. He watches griml as she rides away. At a distance from him she tosses his beside the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven enters. He is dusty and tired from his long walk The place is moderately busy. MED. SHOT of Haven as he sits tiredly at a table where Ch and Prince are sitting. She smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I talked my way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a very glib man. You seem to  talk your way out of everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up to a certain point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gun. (to the waiter) Champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter exits. Charlie looks at Haven curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we celebrating something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) You know, the first time I talked to  you we had champagne. (smiling at her) I think I should have been a  missionary and gone to China after  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out the pipe, twirls it in his fingers. The wait puts down the champagne. Charlie is looking at Haven with puzzlement and curiosity. The waiter goes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you bring me something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her face changes; hardens. She glances across at Prince.  Haven watches Prince with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) No -- just like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's easy to explain. It's just a  little hard to believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it as credible as you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling grimly) I can't. (filling the pipe) I went to get it, and it was there.  But so was somebody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Caslon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... she had a gun with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have one too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one she had was in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a silence. Prince stares idly at the dice cubes his hand. Charlie stares straight at Haven. Haven glances Prince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be that slip you mentioned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Haven) So this nice lady held you up and  took the gold, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like saying I got robbed at  Sunday school. It's no good, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at him) No, it isn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I even had to walk back to town. I  think that may be one of the longest  walks I ever took.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And one of the last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven takes a sip of the champagne, Charlie's whole manne has now changed. It is cold and very quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mick might have killed you, but you  fought him with your fists. The  sheriff had a gun but you took it  away from him. Ben had a gun last  night but it didn't seem to scare  you. Now this genteol petticoat waves  a pistol and you run for your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (twirling the  wineglass, glancing  at Charlie) He makes it sound very silly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or I make it sound like what it is:  a lie! (he rises)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven reaches in his pocket for a match. Prince, mistakin the gesture, swiftly extracts a small pistol from his bel covers him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven extracts the match, with a glance of contempt at Pr then lights the pipe again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling faintly) My word doesn't seem very good around  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've only got one thing left that's  any good here - and that's some gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) Is that all I've got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quite. You've got some time.  You've got two hours to get it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a brief silence that punctuates this statement. has an air of fatal finality, marked by the idle MUSIC of the deaf pianist. Haven puts his pipe away, carefully so  that Prince won't get any mistaken ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to fatten you up before  you kill me? Is that what you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said what I meant -- two hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven rises. He brushes some dust off his coat, smiles th at Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I once knew a guy who stole a dime  tip from a lunch counter and parlayed  it into fifty thousand. I might try  that -- but not in two hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says nothing; her face carved out of ice. Prince smil thinly. Haven looks at him, shrugs. He hesitates; then pa Charlie's frigid shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) You're sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks slowly out. The dirge of the piano fol him. Prince fingers his pistol a little, tempted. At a lo from Charlie he puts it away. Haven goes out. Charlie sud leaves the tables and goes quickly up the stairs. Prince  watches her with a slow smile, picks up Haven's gun and  pockets it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven leaves the saloon. He pauses, looks around, up a the sky, then down the street. He takes out his pipe and  beginning filling it slowly with tobacco, as Mark Bristow comes hurrying across the street. MOVING SHOT of Haven as he walks very slowly, filling the pipe, and Mark comes alongside and walks with him. Haven  hardly glances at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been looking for you. Where  have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took a walk in the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get it for her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (pausing in front of  the hotel) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT of Haven and Mark outside the hotel. Mark is af and puzzled. He keeps staring at Haven's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that was the deal. You agreed to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses as two men walk by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're trying to pull something --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finished with the  pipe) You want to listen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calming himself) All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explicitly) I can't deliver it because I no longer  have it. It was taken away from me  by Mrs. Caslon. I've told Charlie,  and she's very unhappy. I have two  hours to produce the loot. You haven't  any idea where a man could raise  fifty thousand quickly, have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark's mouth pops open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven lights the pipe. Mark stands there, mouth open; fea draining the blood from his face. His voice is a mere whi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, Mark. The boat just sailed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to think of something  very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stares at him, then looks off. His face becomes grim He almost glares back at Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can think of something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patting his shoulder  with a slight smile) Go ahead, Mark. Go ahead and do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stares at him, then turns abruptly away. He hurries  across the street. Haven watches him as he goes off in th direction of Mrs. Caslon. Haven smiles and walks inside t hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters, locks the door. Pulls the shade at the window, takes off his shoes and coat and lies down on the bed. He gazes towards the wall, thoughtfully. He gets up, goes to the window, opens it softly; then looks out. Down the all at the corner, a man is lounging; an ugly looking charact whose eyes watch the alleyway. Haven smiles wryly, goes b to the bed and lies down. The piano music starts next doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing the deaf pianist at the piano, playing. CAMERA PI UP Pete as he enters, FOLLOWS him as he walks up the stai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Pete knocks on Charlie's office door, then enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Pete enters. He looks around. Mick is sitting there an Prince. Charlie is standing at the window. By another doo another grim character stands in silence. Charlie turns a Peter enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got enough men at the sawmill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Go back out there and get  them into the uniforms. We'll hit  the post just before midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete turns and walks out, shutting the door behind him. T is silence. Charlie looks out the window again. Prince fo with the dice. Mick stands stolidly near the door. At las the silence is broken over the ticking of the wall clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what we're waiting for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave him some time. He's in the  hotel. He's not doing anything. I  gave him some time. I don't care  what he does with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has not turned from the window. The clock ticks. From behind her Mick's voice comes, quiet and deadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't care when, but I'll get  him.
