dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mick is silent. Charlie smiles thinly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mark hurries into the saloon, a desperate look on his  face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Charlie turns from the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bristow's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This should be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mick) Let him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mick goes to the door, opens it; just as Mark arrives a l breathlessly at the door. Mark enters, a little surprised the door opening for him, glancing back as Mick quietly s it. Charlie looks coldly at the lawyer who is sweating ag Mark stands there, silent a moment, gathering himself  together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want the I.O.U's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has turned to the safe; now she turns with them and a Mark reaches for them, Charlie drops them at his feet. Th scatter. He bends to pick them up. Prince smiles at him  contemptuously. Mark is picking them up one at a time whe suddenly he pauses, stands erect, and looks at them with  fear and suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Did Haven --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I don't understand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't think they're going to be  any good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stands there. The papers slip from his fingers. He k what Prince means. But his mouth hardens in an effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't have anything to do with  it. All I did was write it. I'm not  in on this. I can still make them  good. (he puts a couple  back on the desk) Or I can --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can do business. (fumbling in his pocket) I got it somewhere. I -- Here --  take a look at this -- the deposition -- (bringing out the  deposition) The only copy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) Let's have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Charlie opens the  envelope) Nothing. I just want to get out of  it. I never had any part of it. This  ought to prove that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him the paper from the envelope. Marks takes it and stares at it. It is absolutely a blank piece of paper He stands there, bites his lips. He looks wearily around them, fear making him weak, making him unable to hold the piece of paper, so that it floats to the carpet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at last) It's -- it's a trick. I -- (trying to pull himself  together) I'll see about this! He can't do  this to me! (moving back towards  the door) I'll go and see about this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, you see about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops dead in his tracks as Charlie moves towards him  with a little pistol, pearl-handled. But she only gives i to him. She has to take his hand and put it in his palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take this along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He backs out, the little gun in his hand. Mick opens the  door. In sudden relief and haste Mark barrels out. They c hear his quick feet on the stairs outside. Prince looks a Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something left to wait for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince gets up and leaves, and Mick, with a grim smile of anticipation follows. Charlie sits slowly down in the cha The music comes up the stairs and through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven is lying on the bed, his arms under his head, his e on the ceiling. There is a SOUND in the hallway and then hurried knock at the door. Haven slowly rises, walks to t door. He stands there. The knock SOUNDS again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me -- Bristow -- let me in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven opens the door. Mark enters swiftly, the little gun his hand. Haven shuts the door and locks it. He turns and faces Mark, now pointing the gun. Without a word Haven wa over to the bed and lies down again, looking at the ceili Mark follows him with the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to shoot me, Mark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You double crossed me, Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the deposition back. I took it  to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven leans on one elbow, looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't there! It was a piece of  blank paper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven lies back with a short laugh. Mark stares at him in fury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you laugh at me! I ought to  kill you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want you to, Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven again leans on one elbow, looking at Mark and the  trembling hand that holds the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it may be your only out, if you  do. But I doubt it. You know why?  Because even if you took them my  scalp, it wouldn't buy your life.  You're in debt and you're broke and  you're scared -- and you know far  too much. There isn't any way they  use you -- alive. Can you think of  one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sits slowly back in the chair, beaten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going to do it. I know it.  They're going to kill me -- (his hand trembles) Why do they have to kill me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Us, Mark...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven gets up slowly, reaches over and takes the little g smiles at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This must be hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dully) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the gun on the table. Mark's teeth are chattering He is almost ready to cry. Haven gets a bottle and pours a drink in a dusty glass. He hands it to Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's one thing, Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gulping the drink) There is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might get out of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't a chance in a thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's one in a million, it's  the only one you have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark gets up waveringly. Takes another hooker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- we might get away with it. We  might...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stares at him. Haven smiles grimly back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you can't stay. You said yourself --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you must do this, go straight to  your horse. Don't stop for anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I've got a lot of important papers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't got anything important  left, Mark -- except your life, and  very little time to keep it. You do  it very fast and you might be lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to pull himself  together) Yes. I might be. I'll try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark hurries out into the hall. Goes. Haven turns back an looks at the room, picks up the little pistol, smiles at Shrugs and then slips into his coat and exits, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven enters. SHOOTING FROM his ANGLE, we can see, as does, Mark crossing the street, apparently towards his la office. He is in such a hurry that he falls down, crawls little, gets up, runs. Just as he reaches the office door just as his hand touches the knob, a shot rings out and h crumples. He still tries, then his hand slips from the kn and he lies there dead. The vacant street is empty with h death. Haven stares. He takes a match from the counter,  applies it to his pipe -- then finding the pipe empty, sm thinly and pockets it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly; turning to  the clerk) You didn't throw away that verse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't have to change it much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the little pistol from his pocket and glances at it. The clerk, watching, idly strumming the guitar string

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't going out there with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never get closer to having  nothin' --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring out) No -- I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm naturally sentimental, bein' a  sort of poet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep a bunch of gimeracks -- an  oldtime sheriff's gun, a bullet from  a dead bandit, a rosary from some  guy they hanged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nice. A hobby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a way -- Want to leave me  something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven smiles. He feels in his pocket, comes out with the  army button gotten at the sawmill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all I seem to have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking it) Army button. (puzzled) Where's the uniform that goes with  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want for -- (he pauses as the  idea hits him) Yeh? A very good question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk stares at him; Haven smiles grimly. He breaks t little gun, checks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might even know. I think I'll try  to go and find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to the door, the little gun in hand; very slowl Watching him, the clerk twangs the strings softly. Haven  walks very slowly. He opens the door and hesitates. Just he is about to step out, looking up and down the street,  there is a furor and the sheriff rides up outside and  dismounts. Starts over to inspect Mark's body. He turns a Haven walks on to the street, hands held high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven emerges and the Sheriff holds a gun on him. ANGLE on Mick as down the street, with disgust, he lowers his gun. ANGLE on Prince as from a doorway he watches. Stopping wi a shake of his head the intent of a man beside him to sho FULL SHOT -- street -- as Haven surrenders to the sheriff

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, you -- march.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven obeys, walking up the street -- the sheriff and the sheriff's horse behind him. People watch, appearing now i safety. The sheriff is pretty pleased. MOVING SHOT -- of Haven and Sheriff. As they go, Haven's  hands still aloft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You loaded your gun for this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back of them can now be seen the figures of Mick and Prin and the other gunman, following at a little distance. Goi leisurely, now Haven slows his pace so that the sheriff i closer behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you! Keep moving!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven suddenly drops to his knees. The sheriff almost wal over him. The sheriff stumbles with an oath. Haven grappl with him. Haven snatches his gun, drags him by a headlock the horse, flings him aside and then mounts. A second lat he is away. Shots RING OUT as Mick and Prince and the gun shoot. Haven rides on, bent low, out of town. The sheriff hides his bulk in the dust as the bullets fly. ANGLE from Charlie's office -- as she goes to the window, stares out at the flying form of Haven. A slow smile come over her face, bitter and grim, yet somehow faintly  admiring... She sees Mick mount a horse and start after H Then she turns abruptly away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven slows down his horse, but goes on at a fair clip after looking warily back. He breaks open the sheriff's g finds it loaded. He reacts and whistles softly. As he swi his horse off the travelled road to head crosscountry for the sawmill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven sits on his horse at a point in the woods where can look down on the sawmill. Around the mill office ther seems to be signs of unusual activity. Haven sees Mick Ma going by on the road towards the mill. Mick passes not fa away and is riding hard. Haven watches as Mick arrives an Pete can be seen in conference with him. Other men -- too many -- are gathered around. At last Haven dismounts and  makes his way carefully on foot towards the warehouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven leaves his horse in the brush and trees and then approaches the building. He finds a window in back, break it with a stone; then waits tensely to see if the sound h attracted any attention, gun in hand now. It doesn't. Hav replaces the gun in his holster, opens the window and cra inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven surveys the piles of crates, boxes and equipment. H starts his search methodically and swiftly. Suddenly a sh of light comes from the front doors opened now by two men Haven shrinks back, drawing his gun. The men start to ent when Pete's voice is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you guys goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want them uniforms out, don't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you when.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men turn and leave. Haven relaxes. He goes back to wo pulls back a big canvas tarpaulin one of the men had  approached, and there before him is revealed the army  uniforms, stacked in neat piles. He looks and smiles grim Outside is the SOUND of horses and more men arriving. Hav goes slowly around the warehouse now, looking for somethi At last he finds it: a can of kerosene. He takes it over the uniforms, pours it liberally on them. At just this mo a figure appears at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you think you're doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven lights a match and tosses it on the soaked bales of uniforms. They blaze up instantly. The man shoots as Have ducks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the shot RINGS out. Pete and Mick, surrounded by many  men, turn swiftly. Flame and smoke emerge from the wareho They start swiftly across, drawing guns. The man at the d shoots again into the smoking interior. An answering SHOT from Haven fells him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven makes his way back to the open window. He crawls out swiftly. Now the building is in flames. He can hear  shouting and, as he moves away, the useless attempt of me to put out the blaze, working with buckets of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven starts for the woods. The flames now light the g around, and Pete appears around the side of the building. Pete fires and Haven draws and shoots. Pete whirls away, but still on his feet, driving forward, trying to shoot a and this time Haven drills him clean and Pete goes down t stay. Other men come up as Haven makes for the woods,  disappears. Mick Marion and a dozen men appear, shooting. Mick sudden changes his mind, turns past the body of Pete, gets his h and heads back to town full tilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven watches the flaming building. The slowly approac figures of the men are illumined in the big light of the  fire. Haven smiles, turns to the horse and moves slowly  through the trees to a place where he can mount; then mou and rides for it, SHOTS following him as he breaks into t clear some hundred yards away and heads for the road that Mick Marion took back to town. Bent low, Haven rides for life -- and makes it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven rides up, a detachment of men supervised by Stel is forming beside mounts in the parade ground. Haven dism and starts inside. He glances at his wagon parked outside It is the one Mrs. Caslon took from him. He smiles slight as he notes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven walks in, brushes past the desk sergeant with a cur nod and enters Iles' sanctum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven enters. Mrs. Caslon is there, and Iles, in full  field uniform. They look at him quickly as he enters; he  pauses, glances at Mrs. Caslon and then faces the explosi Iles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. Just barge right  in! I'm going to tell you something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abruptly) No, you're not. You're going to  listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Iles stares, dumbfounded, at this impertinence:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lost some uniforms? You thought  they were burned?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they weren't, but they are now  because I just set fire to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're smouldering right now in the  warehouse at the sawmill, and there  are about seventy men down there who  were ready to wear them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wear them? What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What other reason? To get in the  post and take the gold from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iles gawks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were taking a detachment up north  on an Indian scare?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iles nods vaguely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that scare is a fake. A ruse.  So you know where to send them now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look here, Lieutenant --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven dips into a lining pocket under his arm and tosses paper at Iles. Iles glances at it, then looks, thunderstr at Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better get down to that sawmill,  Captain. They may try it anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ILES' expression slowly changes. He smiles at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I owe you an apology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extending his hand) I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes hands with Iles for second, then Iles goes out  abruptly. Outside we can hear abrupt commands to the Serg before the door closes. Haven takes out his pipe, looks a the silent, dumb-struck Mrs Caslon. He smiles at her slig She gets her voice at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I owe you something too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only fifty thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside "To Horse" is sounding. Haven glances out the win hardly aware of Mrs Caslon's presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish there was something I could  say or do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is. You can give me back my  gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to the desk, gets it and hands it to him. He tak the gun from his holster and hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you can give this one back to  the sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll always remember what a fool I  made of myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) I always try to forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his own gun in holster. Glances out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching his face) Are you going too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not with them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pats her shoulder in a gesture of goodbye and walks ou the door. She stands watching him, then moves to the wind and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven walks outside towards his waiting horse. He paus pipe in mouth, lighting the pipe now, his face intensely  interested as he watches the men form on the parade groun in front of the mounted Iles and Stellman. FULL SHOT of soldiers. As they mount to a brisk command, the color bearer takes position. Iles barks out a command the column forms into marching order. On the double quick the cavalry company starts out and on the way. CLOSE SHOT of Haven as he watches; his eyes lighting a li the pipe in hand. We feel that he'd like to go too in thi moment. ANOTHER ANGLE from Haven's view, as the column of cavalry departs. Haven waves his hand, a half salute, a half gest to Iles as Iles salutes him in passing. Then only the dus remains and Haven's gaze lingers. His face changes. It be grim. He slowly knocks the ashes from the pipe, pockets i He slowly mounts the horse. He takes out his gun and chec it. Then slowly he rides away, like a man on a mission he dislikes but cannot evade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mrs. Caslon looks out the window. Her face, tense, as watches the lonely figure go; her hand waves slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is standing by the desk and window. Prince is sit there, talking, the inevitable dice in his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's seventy men ready for any  kind of play. I say we can still  swing it -- and get out of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THERE is SOUND of massed horses outside and Charlie looks out. Prince walks to the window. They look in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Iles rides by at full gallop, followed by a troop of  cavalry, headed for the sawmill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they watch. Prince turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to give Haven time. Well,  he took it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better get out before he takes  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By that I presume you intend to  remain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wistfully) I've been here as long as I remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince crosses to the window and stands looking at Charli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked you once if Haven moved me  out. (he smiles) I think he's moved us both out --  together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie looks at him but does not answer and then she tur to the window, and smiles slightly. Prince follows her ga to the street. His face is grim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven, mounted, is coming up the street. Slowly and caref he progresses to the front of the saloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Charlie glances at Prince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) This is the way I wanted it... and  when I've finished you will too...  as though Haven had never been here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and goes quietly and swiftly from the room. Char stands thoughtfully. There is nothing in her look or mann to indicate that what Prince has said has made the slight impression on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven comes up to the saloon door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SALOON DAWN
dialogues.text: As Prince moves into a shadowy corner. ANGLE ON the door as Haven enters and looks around. He se no one. The place seems utterly deserted. It is soundless CAMERA FOLLOWS Haven as he moves slowly. He has replaced gun, but he is alert. ANGLE ON Prince as he watches Haven, now a perfect target not looking in his direction. Prince raises the gun a lit but the dice in his over hand click ever so faintly. SHOT OF Haven as he stops dead in his tracks, hand on the gun again, alert at the slight sound of the dice. Now fac towards the shadow where Prince is hidden. He stands read and rigid for a long still moment. When there is no furth sound or movement, he goes on towards the stairs. ANGLE ON Prince as he moves slightly from the shadow as H goes to the stairs. Prince is ready to shoot again, but n the angle on Haven up the stairs is no good. He lowers th gun with disgust, then moves softly out of the shadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets a gun out of the drawer, looks at it, smiles, dr it back into the drawer, moves around the desk and faces door, composing herself and waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Haven pauses, pushes it open. Then walks slowly in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is standing with her back to the desk, her fingers ti on the edge of the desk as Haven walks in. He stops and l around and then at her. There is a slight smile on her fa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cause me an awful lot of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh... but I finally brought you  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her the little derringer she had given to Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't really think Mark would  use it, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I just wanted to send you a  gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it a little late to make any  difference?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pretty late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to arrest you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could have killed you from the  window -- but I didn't. And I didn't  kill the two men -- or Goodard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe Mick -- maybe Prince -- who  knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts the little gun on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd almost as soon be killed as  arrest me, wouldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which are you -- Wells Fargo or Army?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her the paper he showed Iles. She just glances a it without touching it. Smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it's my turn to wish you'd  gone to China.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I had too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) If you still have that gold, and I  think you do, we might make it yet.  You see I believe that every man has  his price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some men don't believe that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But every woman knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes pass him towards the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only there wouldn't be any women on  my jury. (taking out his pipe) And that's why you're not as bad off  as you might think... I could find  twelve men who might think you capable  of almost anything -- but I wouldn't  bet they'd vote that way after staring  at you through a trial. (he notes her eyes go  past him) Mick is dead for the murders and  Prince can be hung for the rest of  it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bare rustle of SOUND behind him (and the memory of her eyes going past him) Haven whirls, stopping aside and drawing as he does so. And just as he does so, Prince, in the doorway, fires. Haven shoots so that the shots RING O almost simultaneously. Prince topples forward on his knee and then his face. The dice roll out of his unclenched le hand. MED. SHOT of Haven and Charlie as their eyes read the dic Haven puts away the gun. Charlie is still leaning against the desk, but there is a strange look on her face. A thin smile for Haven. Now she sags a little and Haven realizes she has been hit. He starts to her and she turns away tow the couch. He catches her as she sags again, and helps he down gently on the couch. ANGLE on couch as Haven kneels beside her. He starts to p away the top of her dress, but the wound is close to the  heart. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven knows it. He takes her hand and squeezes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get someone --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven stares grimly at her face. She gives him a faint sm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This gets us all. This doesn't count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something -- on the square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds herself tight a moment; then looks at him again the faint smile returning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever -- love me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Tell it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the first night and the first  time of the song. I tried to get  away from it, but every time it came  back. Every time I tried to get it  out of my brain I just pushed it  deeper into my heart. It had to be  either you or me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. I love you... (as he looks hard at  her) Well -- say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to die. He takes her shoulders in his hands as though to kiss her or hold her back to life. Her voice is almost a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you... in China.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes, slumping back. He sits there, pats her shoulder a familiar absent-minded way, then slowly rises. Grimly,  Haven walks out of the room. MOVING SHOT as Haven goes down the stairway. The deaf pia is playing as always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orville is at his old seat behind the desk. He is playing the last verse of the ballad. Haven enters and crosses to his bag, his face blank and grim. He picks up his bag, tu and walks out, as though not hearing the guitar and the  ballad. As he goes into the street --
